#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Write an Artist Statement
#Text=A clear and intelligent artist ’s statement will make you stand out from the crowd and will show people that you are a thoughtful and deliberate artist .
#Text=Writing your statement can be a difficult process , but it is also an enormously valuable exercise as it can help you to achieve a greater understanding of yourself as an artist .
#Text=Here is a helpful guide to steer you in the right direction .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Thinking It Through
#Text=Be honest with yourself .
#Text=Before you write a word , take some time to just think about you and your art .
#Text=You need to understand what it is that you are trying to achieve , before you attempt to explain it to anyone else .
#Text=Ask yourself what you 're doing .
#Text=What does your art express ?
#Text=What makes your art unique ?
#Text=Ask yourself why you 're doing it .
#Text=What motivates you to create art ?
#Text=What emotions or ideas are you trying to convey ?
#Text=What does your art mean to you ?
#Text=Ask yourself how you 're doing it .
#Text=What do you draw inspiration from ?
#Text=What tools and materials do you use ?
#Text=Consider your influences .
#Text=Think about the things that influence you , whether it 's art , music , literature , history , politics or the environment .
#Text=Think about how these influences have made an impression on you and how they manifest themselves in your work .
#Text=Try to be as specific as possible .
#Text=Make a mind-map .
#Text=Mind-mapping is a good way to free your thinking .
#Text=It will also help you to trace the relationship between different ideas .
#Text=Jot down a key idea that informs your work in the center of a blank page .
#Text=Then spend 15 minutes writing down any words , phrases , feelings , techniques etc. related to that idea .
#Text=Free writing is another technique that can help get the creative juices going .
#Text=Spend 5-10 minutes writing whatever pops into your head when you think about your art .
#Text=You 'll be amazed at what you come up with .
#Text=Determine what you want people to understand .
#Text=Think about what you want people to take away from your art .
#Text=What message or emotion are you trying to convey ?
#Text=Piecing It Together
#Text=Make a statement about why you do what you do .
#Text=The first section of your artist 's statement should begin with a discussion of why you make art .
#Text=Try to make it as personal as possible .
#Text=Talk about what your goals are and what you hope to achieve through your art .
#Text=Describe your decision-making techniques .
#Text=In the second section of you statement , tell the reader about your decision-making process .
#Text=How do you select a theme ?
#Text=How do you choose what materials to use ?
#Text=What techniques to utilize ?
#Text=Keep it simple and tell the truth .
#Text=Talk about your current work .
#Text=In the third section , provide some insight into your current work .
#Text=How does it relate to your previous work ?
#Text=What life experiences informed it ?
#Text=What are you exploring , attempting or challenging through this work ?
#Text=Keep it short , sweet , and to the point .
#Text=Your artist statement is an introduction to your work , not an in-depth analysis of it .
#Text=Your artist ’s statement should be one to two paragraphs and no longer than a page .
#Text=Your statement should answer the most commonly asked questions about your art , not overwhelm readers with irrelevant facts and minute details .
#Text=Brevity and efficiency of language are key .
#Text=A good statement will leave your readers wanting more .
#Text=Use simple language .
#Text=An effective artist 's statement reaches out and welcomes people to your art , no matter how little or how much they know about art to begin with ; it never excludes .
#Text=It should make your work more accessible , not obscure it with convoluted language filled with artsy jargon .
#Text=Write in simple , straightforward , everyday language .
#Text=Make " I " statements rather than " you " statements .

column1: #Text=Talk about what your art does for you , not what it 's supposed to do for the viewers .
#Text=Applying the Finishing Touches
#Text=Let it rest .
#Text=Your artist 's statement is a piece of very personal writing .
#Text=Once you 've finished writing , let it rest overnight before your reread it .
#Text=Taking some time will help you take a step back and give you the detachment necessary to polish the writing without violating your sense of integrity and safety .
#Text=Seek feedback .
#Text=Before you go public with your statement , get feedback .
#Text=Show your art and statement to friends , friends ' friends , and maybe even a stranger or two .
#Text=Make sure your readers get it , that they understand what you want them to understand .
#Text=When they do n't , or you have to explain yourself , do a rewrite and eliminate the confusion .
#Text=Keep in mind that you alone are the authority for what is true about your work , but feedback on clarity , tone and technical matters such as spelling and punctuation never hurts .
#Text=Revise as needed .
#Text=Many times , a little rearranging is all that 's necessary to make your statement a clean , clear read .
#Text=If you need help , find someone who writes or edits and have them fix the problem .
#Text=Use your statement .
#Text=Make the most of your artist statement and use it to promote your work to gallery owners , museum curators , photo editors , publications and the general public .
#Text=Save all your notes and drafts .
#Text=Save all the notes and drafts that you 've made .
#Text=You 'll want to revise and update your artist 's statement from time to time to reflect changes in your work .
#Text=Having your original notes and drafts at your disposal will help you to immerse yourself in your past thought processes and will give you a sense of creative continuity .
#Text=Sample Artist Statement
#Text=Doc :
#Text=Artist Statement
#Text=Tips
#Text=Avoid comparing yourself to other artists .
#Text=It can seem presumptuous and you may not come out of the comparison favorably .
#Text=Let the critic 's decide who you 're like .
#Text=Not all artists can write well .

#Text=If you 're in that category , think seriously about hiring a professional writer or editor , preferably one with an art background , to help you convey what you want your statement to convey in language that ordinary everyday people can understand .
#Text=Quick Summary
